column1: Ehrlichiosis is a bacterial infection transmitted by the bite of a tick.
Ehrlichiosis is caused by bacteria that belong to the family called Rickettsiae.
There are 2 types of the disease in the United States: - Human monocytic ehrlichiosis (HME) is caused by the rickettsial bacteria Ehrlichia chaffeensis.
Risk factors for ehrlichiosis include: - Living near an area with a lot of ticks - Owning a pet that may bring a tick home - Walking or playing in high grasses

Symptoms may seem like the flu (influenza), and may include: - Chills - Fever - Headache - Muscle aches - Nausea Other possible symptoms: - Diarrhea - Fine pinhead-sized areas of bleeding into the skin (petechial rash) - Flat red rash (maculopapular rash), which is uncommon - General ill feeling (malaise) A rash appears in fewer than one-third of cases.
Antibiotics (tetracycline or doxycycline) are used to treat the disease.
Children should not take tetracycline by mouth until after all their permanent teeth have grown in, because it can permanently change the color of growing teeth.
Two such infections are: - Lyme disease - Babesiosis, a parasitic disease similar to malaria
Studies suggest that a tick must be attached to your body for at least 24 hours to cause disease.
